_header: The man that will of leechcraft lere
Note: All texts show some variation. Cf. 2687, 2688, 5657, 5656, 6710.
_description: An introduction to a medical tract in prose — generally sixteen couplets

BodAsh1444.First Lines:
þe man þat wylleof lechecraft lereRede over þis boke
                    and he may here…
BodAsh1444.Last Lines:
…Evermore in hevyn to beIn joy with þe
                    trynyte
BodAsh1444.Note:
An epilogue to a medical tract in prose. At the end:
                    ‘AMEN’.

BodAsh1477.First Lines:
The man that wyll off lechecraft lereRede on thys boke and ye may
                    here…
BodAsh1477.Last Lines:
…Euermore in Ioy for to beIn heven with the holy
                    trynyte

OxfAllS121.First Lines:
That man that wele of lechecraft lerered on this book and he may
                    here…
OxfAllS121.Last Lines:
…Euere more in Ioye to bein heuene with the
                    Trinite

CULAdd9308.First Lines:
Þe man þat wele of lechecraft lereRede ouer þis bok
                    & he may hereMany a medicyn boþ good & treweto hele sores
                    boþ olde & newe…
CULAdd9308.Last Lines:
…Be þat on & twenti dayes ben come & gonHe schal
                    be hol boþ flesch & bon

CamTCC1037.First Lines:
The man þat wol of lechecrafte lereReede ouer thys booke &
                    he may here…
CamTCC1037.Last Lines:
…Euer more in ioye to beInne hevyne with the
                    trinite
CamTCC1037.Note:
In different part of MS and by different hand than other copy in this
                    MS.
CamTCC1037.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of Trinity College Cambridge MS O.1.13.
         https://mss-cat.trin.cam.ac.uk/Manuscript/O.1.13.

BLAru272.First Lines:
The man þat welenth leche craft lereRede ouer þis well
                    & he may here…
BLAru272.Last Lines:
…Leue grace her soules haue good restEuer more yn ioye forto
                    be in heuen with þe trinyte

BLHar1600.First Lines:
Þe man þat will of lechcraft lerRed vppon þis boke
                    and he may ler…
BLHar1600.Last Lines:
…Euermor in ioy for to beIn heuen with þe
                    trinite

BLSl140.First Lines:
The man dat wyll of lechecraft lereRede ouer dys book & he may
                    here…
BLSl140.Last Lines:
…Euer mor in Ioye tho beeIn heuyn heoyth de
                    trynyte
BLSl140.Note:
Scribe uses the letter ‘d’ instead of a thorn. Folio number
                    reflects the most recent foliation.

BLSl468.Editions:
Keiser,  George R. 
             “Verse Introductions to Middle English Medical Treatises.” 
             English Studies
         84 (2003): 301-17: 303-4.

BLSl2584.First Lines: Man þat wole of lechecrafte hereRede ouer þis booke & he may lere…
BLSl2584.Last Lines: …Euere more in ioye to beIn heuen with god in trinite
BLSl2584.Note: Written as prose; after end “Amen for charite” (f. 13).
BLSl2584.Attributed Title: A preface of this booke (f. 13, added by a later hand)
BLSl2584.Editions:
Pettigrew,  Thomas Joseph. 
             “Observations upon the Extracts from an Ancient English Medical MS. in
                the Royal Library of Stockholm.” 
             Archaeologia
         30 (1844): 419-29: 421-2.
Henslow,  George. 
             Medical Works of the 14th Century.
         London: Chapman and Hall, 1899: 125.
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 95-6.

AbeUL258.First Lines:
Þe men þat wollen of lechecrafte lererede over þys
                    bok and ȝe may here…
AbeUL258.Last Lines:
…Evermore more in joye to bein hevene wyt god in trynite
                    amen
